content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" emphasizes the need to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials, as stated by the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for expanding opportunities for scientists and researchers and promoting the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in the health professions. Support for institutions in underrepresented communities for workforce development. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to entities committed to health workforce development in underrepresented communities, specifically educational institutions producing underrepresented minority health professionals. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to underrepresented minority health professionals from various educational institutions, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving schools, tribal colleges, and institutions with programs to recruit and retain minority health professionals. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to underrepresented minority health professionals from institutions in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations, forming partnerships to increase workforce diversity. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to underrepresented minority health professionals from institutions with at least 20 percent underrepresented minority participants. Recipients must submit an application containing required information. Funds received will be used to expand, implement, or evaluate workforce diversity programs, including in mental health care professions. Possible activities to enhance diversity in health professions include educational outreach programs, scholarship opportunities, postbaccalaureate programs, academic enrichment programs, health pipeline programs, and mentoring programs. Activities to enhance diversity in health professions include pipeline programs, mentoring programs, internship programs with health entities, community partnership development, and leadership training. Grantees must submit reports summarizing and evaluating grant activities annually. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined in this section. The term "Asian American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined as in the Higher Education Act of 1965. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020. SEC. 5. ELIMINATING DISPARITIES IN MATERNITY HEALTH OUTCOMES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various health organizations, is tasked with addressing disparities in maternity health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with health organizations, will work to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes by conducting research, expanding access to quality maternity care for vulnerable populations, and establishing a demonstration project. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a demonstration project in up to 8 states to compare interventions for reducing disparities in maternity services and outcomes for vulnerable populations. States will be selected based on specified regions and populations served under the project. The Secretary will establish a demonstration project in up to 8 states to compare interventions for reducing disparities in maternity services. Criteria will ensure representation of affected communities, testing of various models, and evidence-based interventions. Demonstration projects will be conducted with local and regional provider organizations for maternity services. The project will run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019, with grants available for evaluation and monitoring. The State participating in the demonstration project must report data to the Secretary for monitoring outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care provided. The Secretary will evaluate the rationale for bundled payment items and services in the project. A final report on the demonstration project results must be submitted to Congress by December 31, 2020. SEC. 6. HEALTH DISPARITIES EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about reducing racial and ethnic disparities in health care. The Secretary will disseminate scientific evidence on racial and ethnic disparities in health care through public awareness campaigns targeting the general public and medical community. The Institute of Medicine Report titled "Unequal Treatment: Confronting Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Health Care" addresses disparities related to age, disability, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation among racial and ethnic minorities. The goal is to disseminate new research findings to healthcare providers and patients to help reduce and eliminate health disparities, including those caused by linguistic and cultural barriers. The curr_chunk discusses the obligation of health providers receiving Federal financial assistance to provide language access services for people with limited-English proficiency, disseminate information on data collection for various demographics, and implement educational initiatives on health disparities. The curr_chunk discusses the authorization of appropriations for programs addressing health and healthcare disparities from 2015 to 2020.
